thread.title: Too early to think of more stimulus: ECB
thread.title_full: Too early to think of more stimulus: ECB | Business Spectator

author: Dow Jones newswires
title: Too early to think of more stimulus: ECB
text:
It is premature to start discussing the possibility of extending the European Central Bank's bond-purchasing program, Estonia's central bank chief Ardo Hansson said on Wednesday.
He said that when the program started this year in March, it had been planned for 19 months. "We are still in the initial phase of the program, " Mr Hansson said, adding it is too early to start "dealing with the issue" of extending it as it has been under way for only six months.
"Everything is possible," Mr Hansson said. "The evolution of these programs depends on developments in inflation. If changes in the inflation rate should be faster or slower, this has an influence."
The comments echo remarks made earlier this week by ECB executive board member Sabine Lautenschläger. Speaking in Milan, Ms Lautenschläger said "it is too early to speak about concrete measures of broadening QE," referring to the ECB's broad-based asset purchase program.
Since March, the ECB has spent €60 billion ($US67.4 billion) each month on mostly government bonds in an effort to revive inflation and growth in the currency bloc. The program is expected to end in September next year, but the ECB has always said that it would last until inflation approaches its medium-term target of just below 2 per cent.
The ECB has intensified its willingness to extend purchases beyond the September 2016 end-date, as inflation rates have hovered near zero for months. In September, eurozone consumer prices fell annually for the first time since the ECB launched its program in March, data showed Wednesday.
Bank of Finland Governor Erkki Liikanen said last week that QE can be expanded if needed to ensure that inflation doesn't stay too weak for too long with damaging economic effects.
